reviews.review_text: Epic game. When i first played this game, I was totally mindblown at how mature the storyline and how beautiful the graphics are.   I was and still baffled how almost nobody in Malaysia knows about this game when it first came out. A problem that still persists up till now.  This is not a game for the kiddies but I am sure this kind of game is recommended for people to understand gray moral choices that will somewhat help in real life decisions.  The drawback:  - controls are sometimes clunky (sometimes not being able to hit monsters when the target reticule is not on it, or Geralt performs a heavy attack when in actual you're pressing the light attack button)  - crashes frequently when I load a save game (happens when there is a bloat of save games)  - Tiring grind to get loads of gold to get and craft the Dark Armour Diagrams and materials. (you can only get Dark Armour in Dark Mode)  The Pros:  - Great Mature Storyline - Great Graphics for a 2011 game - Decent Moral Choices - Difficult Combat for newcomers but it will grow on you once you get the hang of it! (Pro Tips: DODGE! DODGE! DODGE!) - A developer who has managed to stay independent and still able to developed this great game - No DRM if you register the steam version on  GOG.com  for a backup copy for free! (the developer's subsidiary company that manages DRM-less games)  Buy this game to encourage more independent developers to churn out great games like this.  Plus, the sequel The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt is coming out in February 2015. You will certainly have a better insight on the story if you played this first. Hey, even better if you buy both the Witcher 1 and Witcher 2!  This game is an AAA title (in terms of quality) in my list and one of few many games that i have replayed more than twice.  P.S. - Best played with a controller. Contains nudity and simulated sex

The Witcher 2 is one of the most mature, enthralling, entertaining games I've played in years. If this isn't at least nominated for 'Game of the Year' I don't understand the Gaming Industry anymore. The graphics are amazing, the music is beautiful, and the game features some of the best quests I've seen in a long time. Everything from monster slaying, to hot chick laying, to a 'Hangover' style quest where you have to retrack the previous night drunken revelry. This game is a MUST for RPG fans.  POSSIBLE CON: The story continues immediately after the Witcher 1 and does NOT hold your hand. If you want background on characters or plot devices either play Witcher 1 or go wikipedia the storyline and get caught up.

One of my all-time favourite games. Geralt of Rivia has never looked better than here, everything about this game still impresses me. They took the first game and improved on almost everything except the stances..bring back the fighting stances . This came out the same time as Dragon Age II which i also purchased and i have to say after that dissapointment i could have kissed CDPR's feet after playing this gem 7 times to completion. The game requires you to play it twice to get the full story...but i just loved it that much. The dev is also awesome and deserves everyones support, they actually treat us with some respect and not cash cows .  EDIT : Unbelievable but they actually did it ! Witcher 3 is better than this amazing title.  Its really something special when a dev improves on each game in a trilogy MANY other large companies could learn a thing or two from these guys.

Now, really, can you say something bad about  Witcher  games in general? The series are pinnacle of RPG gaming, and developers really tried to present the best RPG experience to the gamers, and, I dare to say, they succeeded.   The story of  Witcher 2: Assassins of Kings  takes place after the first game. Someone blamed you for murdering a King, and you set off to find out the culprit. Simple as that, but, the story is also about Geralt regaining his memories.   The graphics are quite good and enchanted in relation to the first  Witcher  game. Attentions to the small things are amazing, from the detailed characters and environments to special effects, and  Witcher  is a truly an eye candy for gaming masses. In regard to that, you really need a high end PC machine to play the  Witcher 2: Assassins of Kings .   The world of  Witcher  is huge and along the way you will meet a bunch of interesting characters, have a lot of...virtual sex, fight many kind of monsters, etc. Sometimes the game feels a bit to grindy, but your choices and fights you are engaging yourself into really impact the outcome of the story. Sometimes the battles seem a bit to tough, and RPG beginners could find the game more challenging, but, once you gain enough experience under your belt, the battles become easier.   All  Witcher  games are highly recommended, and this one is no exception. This is simply something best that RPG games can offer. Don't miss it.
Note: At the time of this review I have completed both The Witcher 1 & 2, but not 3. This review, to some extent, assumes you have only played TW1 and contains minor spoilers for it.    Overview

An awesome game for adults, a must buy.  Pros: + great and mature story + Geralt of Rivia + Badass characters + in the middle of the game you can take one of two paths, and both are really different from each other + good replay value + good graphics + awesome soundtrack + epic swords and powers + neat side quests  Cons: - carry weight (had to use a mod) - not really good optimization  - the targeting system is clunky  - no fast travel - the auto-save here sucks, kept using F5 button - the NPCs always slam the door in your face (lol so rude)  final verdict: 8/10

Right after i finished number 1, i started with the second witcher game. And I can safely say I am pleased with this game. This game has the perefct balance between story, gameplay, and game lenght. There's quite a bit of dialog, but if you dont like it, you can just skip the talking.   This is a rpg game for adults. There's politics, ethical problems, and a bunch of hard choises to make. I spent about 35 hours, and I did almost everything the game has to offer. There's an arena mode wich does not have anything to do with the story of the game, where you fight against increasingly hard waves of enemies, wich game me an hour of enjoyment, but you can play it for quite a bit.   In summary, this is one of the best games I have played. The story is amazing, and i was caught in the situations of the game at all times. I was suprised when the game was finished, since I didn't feel time flowing. The gameplay is an HUGE upgrade from the last one, and skill is a bigger factor than stats. The lore and immersion is fantastisc, i actually went through all the books i found. It altso looks amazing, still, in 2016.   This one is among the best games I have played, and it deserves a 10/10. Now, I'm starting the third, and probably the last game in the series. Va'fail!
Witcher 2 was just a story about how Letho decided to troll Geralt for the lulz.﻿

Awesome game. I initally had a hard time getting into it, as I found it was harder than most rpg's that I play ( I'm a big fan of Dark Souls and Demon's Souls, though the Witcher 2 difficulty is different from those kinds of games. ) I also found it akward to play with a keyboard, and once I switched to a controller, my gameplay satisfaction significantly increased. Once I got through the first chapter, I hit my stride then and figured out how to be a more effective Witcher, and the initial learning curve was overcome. Gameplay is good, coupled with really good fighting animations, proves for a satisfying experience. Graphics and audio are very well done; the game has a satisfying and fitting soundtrack. The story is interesting, and I always felt compelled to find out what happens next. However it does allude to the first game quite a bit, and while it does fill in some details for you, it may be better to play through the first game, but in my opinion it is not absolutely necessary. The game also features multiple meaningful choices and there are several endings to obtain, giving alot more playabilty. All in all I would highly recommend it.
The only RPG that doesn't tell you your choices matters and it actually matters a lot as with your choices everything in the game changes.

The Witcher series is amazing, right up there with the likes of Dragon Age and Mass Effect. Great story, good graphics, good (but hard) gameplay, and great RPG elements. Combat skills, spells, potion crafting, and hard choices which greatly alter the story makes this a complete package RPG. Can't wait for the next-gen third installment.

If you are lover of RPG games , this is something for you . The story is epic and gameplay too and the graphick is awesome too . This game is one of the games you will never forget and you wanna play it again and again . There are a-lot sex scenes and they are really good I have to say . I rate 9,5/10 . And I recommented to all of you ! You have to buy this game !
Good combat, good graphics, good story, decent play time and boobs, don't forget the boobs.

Pros:    Long and Captivating Story   Choices, Choices, Choices...   Fluid Combat   Fun Mini-Games   Superb Graphics   Sex and Romance   High Replay Value   Okayish Arena Mode   Save Game import Feature   Cons:    Insane Difficulty   Needs Sprint feature :/   Some Side Quest Bugs   Limited Skill Tree points   Dialogue Cutscenes aren't intense    Definitely one of the Best RPG Games out there  9.5/10

While I had to use an xbox 360 controller to enjoy the game, it is a ery solid RPG. The story telling is solid and original. The game starts out on rails but opens up a lot. The bulk of the gameplay is town-base with surrounding countryside questing. The player decides what objects to pursue and how to develope his charcter. THe towns are just the right size and have interesting npcs.

Really, I could probably summarize Witcher 2 by saying it's an improvement over the original in almost every game-related way that matters, subjective things like atmosphere and alike being debatable, because CDPR upped their game significantly and actually worked with the engine of their own making, but that would be an easy way out and I like to complicate my life.  First notable change is a clear 180 towards making the game into a more action-based installment, further enforced by removal of old combat styles and instead focusing on light and heavy attacks which give you more freedom in a sense that you can combine them on the fly without getting locked into a carefully choreographed sequences. Other than that there are changes which I would tentatively summarize as 'streamlining done right' which is quite a claim in this day and age – alchemy removes the need for alcohol basis which finally lets Geralt stop being a walking cellar lugging around all kinds of high quality alcohol. It should also be noted that changes like these don't really simplify the game in any significant fashion primarily because other elements, like actual gear variety, addition of proper crafting and traps, etc easily offset whatever may have been removed. That's not to say everything is perfect because some people had problems with the way combat works and overreliance on Quen aka protection Sign as a crutch, but I never really went through those problems so I can't testify to that.  Story and characters of the game are an entirely separate beast worthy of being mentioned on their own. Witcher 2 continues after the first game, but works perfectly fine as a standalone story, although it is HIGHLY recommended that you're familiar with the original to understand who's who and what's happening in general. It retains the same old moral ambiguity and holds back no punches for the player but it's even better this time around thanks to increased world reactivity as well as choices & consequences which are really cranked up to 11. Fact that Act 2 is different depending on a choice you make previously practically guarantees at least two playthroughs to get the entire story and even then you'll still miss some modular things which can be done differently. Even though the stakes have escalated as far as the story goes, it's still a story very much grounded in reality except you now get to dabble in politics beyond just a cursory introduction.  In the end Witcher 2 gets a resounding thumbs up from me. Importing your old Witcher 1 save file is also recommended. Not so much for the imported gear you'll replace fairly quickly so much as for decisions you made previously.

I bought this game for $2.50 and all I can say is, wow. After purchasing the first and second games for the price of a chocolate milk, I have spent over 85 hours on the games. I really enjoyed the first one, then when I played this it blew my expectations out of the water. The story, the characters, the settings, but most of all the highly improved sword and fighting mechanics. I finally felt in control of Geralt.   This game was smooth and well polished at the time of playing. Although some of the game seemed quite easy, it regularly proved to be difficult in others requiring you to think about your steps. Not challenging enough to make you give up, but enough to really involve you in the battle. Yet, this is where my one complain of the game comes up. You cannot consume any of your alchemy items or oil your blade once the fight has started. A lot of the time you may not know who you are going to fight or when. Since all consumables are timed, you don't want to always use them up. This meant sometimes saving your game, running around, loading back to the previous save to know what you should consume. I hope in the 3rd title this is changed back.   Over all, amazing game. Will play through again since the story can go 2 ways. I want to see both paths that Geralt takes and am really looking forward to playing through again.   Also want to see how many boobies I can convince women to show me since so far it's 100% more in this game than real life.
The Witcher 2, the game that has a great story, great characters, nice items, but the rest is ♥♥♥♥.  Play it with mods, it will be better.

Awesome game, great unique story, complex and very interesting characters,,, intesive gameplay and difficult choices to make. Cant wait to see my choices have influence on the withcer 3, which I'm buying pretty soon.

This review is from the perspective of a new player to the series. Yes I have “played” the first witcher but dropped it after realizing how broken the game play is.  The points: + Controller support + Combat + Dialog + Characters + Art/Level Design + Solo + One Ring to Rule Them all/ Lesbomancy  ~ Animation ~ Story (my bad) ~ Menus  - The world - Short - Triss’s BS  8/10  -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------  Okay let's start off with the middle ground issues, the ones that were annoying but didn’t break it for me. The animation at times was great the problem is the other 50% of the time they look like ventriloquist dummies, which is worse than the Mass effect stare. The story is very hard to follow and get into the swing of understanding it however after about 3 hours in I could fully understand what was going on. The menus leave much to be desired but it’s a huge step up from witcher 1, it took about an hour to get used to after that didn’t have much issue.  Now the negative, the world makes no sense I don’t understand how 8 tiny countries smaller than rhode island can pump out more then the huge southern nation. I’m sorry but these nations are conquered. The story is short like COD level game short for a RPG. And Lastly Triss’s ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t, this is not a damsel in distress issue. The issue with Triss is it’s obvious by the 80% mark of the main story that ALL this time she has been lying and manipulating you, BUT NOTHING COMES OF IT. no dialog, no nothing, I’ll be starting Wild Hunt sometime today if this is not brought up I will mark that game down as well for this.   Now for the good, I glad this game has controller support because rolling around using a keyboard would have been a massive pain. And it’s done very well, I have some issues with inventory but besides that everything was handled well. The combat is actually combat in this game I can sense hints of Dark Souls, which isn’t bad because this game has a better combat system then Dark Souls (no one likes a game that ques your button presses). The dialog is not Mass Effect level crap of good, funny, and mad. It’s actually a bunch of options that may lead you to what you need. The Dialog system shines best with the Golem in the mission The Secrets of Loc Muinne. The characters are properly developed and have depth to back them except for Triss(her whole character is “she wants your D” -.- not joking). The world is beautiful and the levels are large enough for the time spent in each area to make it worth it. And lastly the solo experience, this is Geralt’s story not “Geralt and his friends” story. At first I thought I would hate this, but as time went on it made you feel more awesome. Do to the fact you were doing everything on your own.
One of the best RPG’s in a long time, with a complex and engaging story, very well developed characters and gorgeous graphics. A must for fans of fantasy.

Amazing RPG. Exactly what a sequel should be. Great storyline that reveals as you play through the game and just keeps pulling you in more and more. Beautiful graphics, great voice acting and as usual UNIQUE and AMAZING soundtrack. Combat is refined since the first game and is good enough to provide a challenge but could be better. I reccomend to play the game at Dark or Insane difficulty to get the absolute maximum feeling from it. If you import a save from the first Witcher don't expect to see a lot of the choices made there have some influence here. The game itself has many choice which affect a lot in the game (and except a lot of things to be affected in the Witcher 3) therefore it has replayability value. Overall i recommend this game. One of the top 5 RPG's i've ever played!

The Witcher 2: Assassins Of Kings is an incredible game. It has great graphics, great gameplay, awesome characters and dialogue, a fantastic soundtrack, a fascinating universe and lore, an incredible storyline and the best political intrigue I have ever seen in a video game. It is awesome how the choices you make affect the game and how the branching paths differ from each other, giving you the chance to experience the game's story from two opposite perspectives. The only problems I have with the game are the interface, which is hard to navigate, and the hit detection is kind of weird, but the latter is quite easy to get used to.  Overall it is a brilliant game.
A game with boobies and an EXCELLENT storyline? I'll take that. 1,000,000/10
The best RPG game I have ever played. Deep mature story, interesting characters, unexpected choice consequences and beautiful graphics. Why haven't you already bought it?

Drawing from it's rich source material the Witcher 2, continues the tale of Geralt of Rivia as he seeks to uncover the truth behind a mysterious group of assassins who are after royal blood. Building on the amazing story which started with the first Witcher game, considered a classic by many, Witcher 2 also improves the experience of being a professional monster-slayer. The combat is challenging and realistic ( no chugging fifty potions in the middle of a fight :P ) and the visuals and voice acting are excellent, and the story as aforementioned is gripping filled with impactful choices, characters that you will grow to love and others whom you'll want to introduce to a witcher's blade.   For those who have played the Witcher 3 Wild Hunt and want to immerse yourself more in the witcher world but find the first witcher to have not aged particularly well Witcher 2 Assassins of KIngs is an excellent game detailing Geralt's adventures leading upto the events of Wild Hunt.   Overall an amazing RPG and good entry point for those who have never played a Witcher game as well as returning monster-slayers.

The Witcher 2: Assassins of Kings one of the best RPGs ever made  The Good: -Great Story and decision making -Great Gameplay -Awesome Soundtrack -Good Voice Acting -Beautyful Graphics and level design -Interesting Characters -Better Romance scene than in any Bioware game  The Neutral -Not that many Armor/Weapon items -No Sprint, i used almost all the time the 2/2 Combat roll to get faster from point A to B -Potions are not Usable while in combat  The Bad -Act III was somewhat dull and very short -At the end i was somewhat OP i 1 - 3 hitted almost everything and did take almost no damage even in the endboss fight  I'd rate 9/10, must have for RPG fans

Another stellar CRPG entry by CD Projekt Red.  With each release Geralt, and The Witcher universe, becomes more and more compelling...  The graphics are stunning, the story deep, and the combat is enjoyable (although, there is a learning curve, people).   + Cd Projekt Red appear to be one of the last Developers not wholly overtaken by the corporate bottomline as they actually appear to like their customers and treat the fanbase very well.
Not so great as the first game, but still immersive and fascinating. RPG-lovers, that's a 'must play' for you.

'11/10, only for the nudity' -My friend.  No but seriously, great game- one of the best RPG's I've played.   -Combat system is great. It feels very smooth. -Alchemy is very dynamic. -Story is also fantastic. It flows well, and it manages to make a long story very interesting.

If you liked the first witcher then this game is definitely for you. If you never played the first witcher but like RPGs then this game should be given a chance. Gameplay is fun and never felt boring. Story was engaging with a good amount of replayability to see what would happen if you did a scenario differently. Then there's the ♥♥♥♥ factor which was a fair amount.     Only problem I have with this game is that it never fixed the issue that Witcher 1 had with side quests. Sometimes if you did a certain quest before another quest one of the quests cancels or even sometimes if you want somewhere the game doesn't warn you you won't be able to return (I guess which gives a poor reason to come back and play again).   Other than that when I got this game for $4, it was one of the best $4 I spent in a while.

This sequel really lives up to the name. The battling system, character development and abilities have been completely changed. I am playing it on a very high difficulty level as that is the only way for unique items to be available in the game, so I'm not sure if the battling is challenging on the lower settings. My experience so far has been a difficult one so far :) The graphics engine is absolutely amazing and if you have a beast of a machine you will fully enjoy the beauty of this game. I sometimes just stand around and admire the landscape. As with the first Witcher there are some of mini-games for you to spend some time on. Whether you are a Witcher fan or not.. this is an exceptional RPG!

CD Projekt weaves an impressive, mature & complex storyline that evolves based on your decisions. I'm really in awe seeing how my choices made a deep impact. In one playthrough,   Geralt aided the murder of a king. (He deserved it!)   In another,   Geralt was a liberator  . The third time, our 'hero' was in it for himself reigning death & having mobs have their way.  Other games are just too linear by following a single path to a given destination.  The Witcher 2  destroys the mold by varying the direction of the game. By the 2nd chapter you've chosen a side which massively affects everything: allies may now be enemies, where you end up is completely different, and those you saved may have dire consequences later on.  With multiple endings, I highly recommend this RPG.

One of the greatest RPGs ever made. The biggest positive of this game is it's non linearity- there are many difficult choices that we will have to make. Second chapter of the game looks completly different depending on our previous decisions. The story is pretty decent, just a bit 'too political' in my opinion, but all those movie-like cutscenes are downright gorgeous. It just makes it really easy to feel involed in what's going on. Combat is ok, sort of a tactical hack & slash. It's up to us whether we'll help ourselves with magical signs, traps, potions or with little of everything. The only two flaws that I can think of is difficulty arch (game is hard at the beggining and gets quite easy later), and the fact that it could really be longer. Takes 20+ hours to finish the main story, and 30+ hours to finish it with all the side quests. But still I think it's a great game and I'd recommend it to anyone who likes action RPGs.

The Witcher 2 grabs ones attention with it's stunning graphics and well designed environments but it's the compelling story lines which keeps the player coming back for more. What makes The Witcher 2 unique from other RPGs is the ability for the player's actions to have a real effect on the progression of the story lines and similarly the world around them. Even the side quests are interesting elements of this game and can also make a difference on how things pan out. Although there are some linear sections sprinkled throughout the game, the developers have done a good job ensuring these don't feel too constraining to the player. For gamers who enjoy well written and in depth story lines, The Witcher 2 is definitely worth a play through; however for those who aren't interested in complex story lines and prefer more focus on hacking and slashing this might not be the game for you.

MY FAVOURITE GAME OF ALL TIME (BARRING WITCHER 3) IS ALSO A STEAL!  $5 during a Steam Sale. 100 hours played. That's less than 5 cents an hour for entertainment. Now THAT is value. Awesome game, awesome price. Do yourself a favour and buy it.

Before we proceed, understand that I actually like the gameplay in The Witcher 2. In fact, it's exceptional. Combat is easy to play yet hard to master – an elusive quality in action RPG combat mechanics – with plenty of difficulty and interesting combat scenarios. By the end of the incredibly well put-together tutorial, you'll feel like you honestly participated in medieval siege. A rich and complex crafting system underpins plenty of gameplay interactions and makes many of the incidental bits of junk you collect through the game have real value. And on top of all of this, The Witcher 2 is one of those rare RPGs that flirts with having real consequence to player decisions throughout the dialogue.  Thus, I feel I have to give The Witcher 2: Assassins of Kings a good review score; by every objective standard of game design, development, and production values, it is an excellent game. I cannot recommend it unreservedly, however, as a few things about the game never quite clicked into place for me. I found myself, at the end of it, more stricken by some of the evident gaps in story and gameplay direction than enthusiastic for the inevitable sequel that, presumably, will tie together the numerous loose ends of the storyline.  The first Witcher was a game that I had a very hard time playing through. On the one hand, I loved the writing and variety of choice available throughout the dialogue and intrigue portions of the game; on the other hand, most of the momentary gameplay was painfully overcomplicated and obtuse. Any game requiring that I explicitly enter combat mode and then explicitly choose a stance before I can start wailing on dudes loses points in my book. The Witcher 2 eschews many of the more glaring flaws of the original game—a more streamlined UI, a closer camera so you can really see what's going on, and a combat system that emphasizes skill are all welcome additions to the series.  There are some distinct flaws in the gameplay, though nothing major. The first and most obvious one is how side quest objectives are communicated. The Witcher 2 has joined the slew of recent games that basically lead you through the objectives to complete side quests (and, actually, main quests) by hand. While I have some objections to that in general, my complaint in this case is more about some of the little gaffes in how that's presented.  The next major flaw in the gameplay is that autosaving is used in the game, but not always in intelligent ways. At some boss fights, the game will autosave right before the big introduction cut-scene of the boss. This makes sense if you walk away from the game for a few days after dying to the monster once; but if you're like me, and try again... several times... then needing to blunder through the cut-scene time and again becomes a real nuisance.  The third major flaw is that there are unique gameplay modes – such as stealth – which will activate contextually, but you are explicitly told to enter them. Since the game decides when you enter into the mode, why are you telling me to go into the mode? What button is that? Not a big deal by any means, but a little irritation all the same.  Graphically and aurally, the Witcher 2 is a very well put-together game. Lush visuals, fantastic texture work, great visual effects, and clear iconography keep the game attractive.   The music is, by and large, very fitting, and the sound design tactfully places you in the middle of the events of the game. Lots of nice little touches – folks chopping away at wood in a little village, the crumbling of nearby rocks as you climb down a cliff face, or the occasional snap of twigs as you tromp through the forest – pop out of the speakers regularly. Voice acting is also quite good.   I think I take the most issue with the writing and character design. By and large, the Witcher series has a very dim view of most people. Just about everyone is an ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ in The Witcher 2; even Geralt's sorceress girlfriend, the character who the writers tried hardest to make sympathetic, comes off as a catty, jealous ♥♥♥♥♥ at times. It's not that I believe people are always nice and friendly, but when there's not a single decent person to talk to, it gets hard to take any of the characters seriously.  The other side of this is that some of the best written, most charismatic and genuinely fun characters to be around don't last terribly long. This is made abundantly clear by the end of the tutorial. Apparently in Witcher world, fun people aren't fit to live.  By the end of the game, I found myself left with a distinctly ashen taste in my mouth; the victories are left hollow and incomplete. Partially because the ending doesn't fully resolve the numerous sub-plots of the game, but also because the storyline felt arbitrary and disconnected. The Witcher's style – weirdly dark and artificially edgy, especially for a fantasy title – creates disjointed storylines that, even when the promised ending occurs, are a letdown.  I also might mention that The Witcher 2 represents a... particular view of women. If you are comfortable seeing women portrayed as little more than ♥♥♥♥ and ♥♥♥, then this is the game for you! If, on the other hand, you find the lack of strong female characters in games to be irritating, then this really isn't for you. Triss and Ves, two of the notable female characters of the game, don't count, by the way; both spend most of their screen-time in form-fitting outfits, prancing their overly shapely asses about the focus point of the camera and generally requiring Geralt's manly help to accomplish much of anything.  Despite all the little flaws and caveats, The Witcher 2 is, ultimately, a fantastic game; any fan of darker, more consequentialist fiction will find themselves right at home. Nevertheless, those of you looking for something more upbeat, more uplifting – and frankly, less draining to play – will want to look elsewhere. The Witcher 2 is bittersweet.
One of the best RPG games ever made.   After all these years, it still remains a masterpiece. Story, gameplay and soundtracks are superb. The game stands the test of time.

Haunting and atmospheric just like the first in the series, and very fun and challenging to play through. The series seems to be becoming more action/adventure oriented than an RPG meant for purists, but what this game does it does very well. The combat system has become more oriented toward player skill rather than Geralt's attributes, but this turned out to be pretty fun once I got the hang of the controls. Branching storylines encourage replayability, as in the first game. At first I had a problem with the excessive use of bloom and shader effects, though these things are implemented far better and more artistically after the first chapter, so I suggest everyone keep these settings enabled. Overall this is a very well-written and clever game and I would recommend it to fans of the first game or fans of the fantasy fiction genre in general. You won't be disappointed!

Some my Pros/Cons  Pros:  + Mod support + Ritch storyline + Nice looking visuals even on low settings + Perfect soundtracks + A lot of craftable items + High quality NPC voice acting + Fun during monster hunt (preparing traps/poisons/reading up on the creatures etc)  Cons:  - Unrealistic sword combat. It doesn't feel right.  - Unbalanced gameplay mechanics - Oils and potions barely last long enough to be of any use, and forcing you to drink them in meditation mode is tiresome. Also fairly unrealistic and breaks immersion somewhat. Many skills over/underpowered (i.e. dodge-roll, shield sign, alchemy tree etc.) -Clunky UI and menus. Bad sorting options, unintuitive selection design (i.e. hover over recipe with mouse cursor, then press space or enter to complete recipe. but don't click and make sure not to move your mouse away from recipe in list). The map, while looking totally freaking awesome, is almost entirely useless. Many more problems with UI. -Lack of camera controls and options. -Unclear or non-existent tutorials. -Also, doors. OMG DOORS. Another obvious piece of the game programmed with the fortcoming console port in mind.  Overall. 6/10. I can recommend Witcher 2 if you are keen on fantasy setting and magic items crafting...

The Witcher 2 is an exemplarary sequel that manages to build upon the strengths of the Witcher 1, namely it's combat mechanics and plot twists, while addressing and improving on it's predecessor's flaws . An outstanding Role Playing Game, no two replays of this game will ever be the same. In the Witcher 2, you are thrust into the character of Geralt of Rivia, famed monster slayer and unintended savior of a king, where you must make the decisions that alter the fates of not only the protagonist but the world and its many characters about him. Its a compelling narrative about maintaining neutrality in a world that is morally ambiguous and deceptive. You will feel the sting of unintended consequences, and with a variety of supporting characters, all whose lives and motivations you will come to understand, decisions in this game are not made lightly . Aside from its storyline, the actual mechanics of the gameplay are superbly executed. Combat is visceral and tactical. Magic, Alchemy, and swordplay are your means of defeating your enemies, and the Witcher 2 introduces a menagerie containing all sorts of monsters, both fantastically gargantuan & sometimes human, whose strengths/weaknesses must be taken into account, especially on the hardest of difficulties. In the end, the Witcher 2 is a satisfying video game with a storyline that leaves it's impression upon you because of it's relation to your impact as Geralt. I'm optimistic about this franchise and look forward to future sequels.

The Witcher 2 is unlike any rpg that came before, because of one word only 'story.' The witcher 2 might not offer a open world but what it does offer is a great story. Have you ever been lured in to a rpg with them saying 'choice will change your game.' Well, The witcher delivers in aces, not only will your choice change the future, but where you are in the world and the people you meet. Sure the're are set pieces and story character you have to meet, but i found they always had something new to say or a new quest for you to do. The choices witcher 2 supplies has you picking from one evil or another evil, with no one being greater than the other. You don't gain lightside or darkside points, you just are the way you chose. Combat is pretty straight forward, you have a sliver sword that kills monsters and a iron sword to kill humans. Potions can be consumed before a fight to say increase your ability to dodge incoming attacks or see in the dark. Geralt of rivia has large skill tree, and each point you put it makes you feel stronger, wither it be strength, wisdom, or alchemy. Geralt the character you lead through this adventure is a anti-hero to a T. Geralt's profession is monster slaying, with a bit of humans on the side. All and all I enjoyed the game, set paths and hand holding hurt the opening, but what is to follow is indeed a rpg to be had. P.S with your steam purchase you also get the game 'DRM free' from Good Old Games website as well.

BUY THIS GAME  V.I. - variable immersion -> You can immerse yourself in the witcher world as much as you like. The harder mode you select the more you will be immersed. Killing a monster makes you feel like a real witcher , because it requires skill and THOGHT.  Great side missions -> The side missions are NOT repetitive. The Witcher 2 isn't a perfect game. The inventory system is pretty terrible compared to Witcher 1's, blade oils and potions have been downgraded significantly (and the timers for them, now reduced to a few minutes at most, don't seem to pause during dialogue, meaning if you don't skip through dialogue after reading the subtitles you might spent several potions and oils preparing for a fight only get into a pre-fight dialogue and have them all unwittingly wasted away), and the magical signs in turn have been buffed to the point of almost being broken, with Yrden in particular rendering most bosses trivial. The dice poker is now a single-round exercise in trying to move your mouse as microscopically as you can in order to not cause every dice to go canonballing off of the board, and the fistfighting diversion is now just a bunch of QTEs.  But when you look past all that, The Witcher 2 is by far one of the better RPGs of its generation. The dialogue and general writing are great, and the politics and general lore are more fleshed out and interesting than in the first game. The quest design in general has been greatly improved, and even though there are less monster hunting quests than in the first game they're generally deeper, involving you researching the monsters and doing specific goals to fully eradicate the threat instead of just lobbing off a few heads and turning them in. The game is overall shorter than the first game, but only because it branches off after the first chapter and essentially becomes two different stories which then further branch out, leading to plenty of replayability. You'll have forgotten all of the flaws I listed up above within the first chapter of the game, and it's overall definitely worth a purchase if you're into RPGs.

All in all, this is an awesome game - highly recommended. Can't wait for #3!

if you ever thought that fairytales and fantasy creatures are just for kids then you didnt have the chance to take a glimpse of the world of the witcher where power corrupted politics meet dangerous bloodthirsty creatures.  The witcher is an rpg game franchise with characters based on short story collections that later became a saga of novels writen by a polish writer Andrzej Sapkowski.Cd projekt red is the team that took this fantasy world into the pc.The story is about a witcher named geralt of rivia.Witchers are mercenaries,hunters of mythical beasts hired even by kings.In the second part of the saga, the kings of the north are slayed by mercenaries and one of them in front of geralt who is accused of the murder as he was found alone with the dead body of the king.The tale starts as he is trying to clear his name by finding and killing the murderer.   The visual design of the game is plus moderate compared to 2014 games as when it was published was on the top of the rpg games.The lanscapes, the cities, the alleys, models everything on it made me feel as i was part of a graphic novel, living, breathing in it.The game as a whole made me explore every alley of it remembering every path of the map by heart. It resembles the fable saga in a significantly darker tone in a cruel world with nudity and teriffying creatures.   It worked in general on high frames except the third act where i found it drop at 15-20 frames.It is still a heavy game.Ι also want to point that there is no support for 2560-1080 screens.I used the flawless widescreen app to play it on full screen.   It took me 35 hours to clear the game but without some sidequests that i missed as it was my original first gameplay, so i think that it provides 38-40 hours of playtime. Surviving in this world depends not only on your sword skills nor your magic skills but as a combinbation of everything that is provided. I discovered that on the hard way as i died again and again on the first hours. I saw the game-over screen many times, the loading screen is the fastest i have ever seen and after finishing the evil within it was like paradise. Runes ,enchantments,oils,poisons,potions traps everything are essential for survival. I found myself using everythimg on my disposal for the first time.Υou dont play a witcher ,the game is made to make you feel that you are one and acting as one .The inventory menu needs some improvement though. Magic is just for support dont expect to make a mage character. Αs for the sword fight, is immersive but with some problems when it comes to multi-fights.   Closing this review i want to add that choices does matter on this one and depending on what you choose, you affect politics and play different quests.So it provides different gameplay build everytime.Plus you can import your witcher 1 save and depending on your inventory and your story path you acquire some swords and coins on your witcher 2 start and in a few occusions it affects the game but dont except really big changes. Have fun !!!  mediun to high hardware : sapphire r9 280x toxic intel celeron G1620 2,70 ghz 6gb ram sandisk ultra ii ssd 120gb sata3 lg 29um65-p  running on windows 8.1 maxxed out  + 1) wonderful visuals even compared to 2014 games + 2) resourceful type of combat  + 3) choice-consequences system + 4) great videos and multiple ways of storytelling  - 1) the story doesnt feel adequate enough, needs more depth - 2) doesnt support ultrawide screens

I loved Witcher 1 from the moment I played the demo shortly after it had been released. I loved the graphics, the atmosphere, the world, the minigames, the humour ('We really ought to get the mill checked out by a witcher!'), I even came to like (kinda sorta) the fighting system. The story was brilliant, if sometimes confusing.   So, naturally, I was deeply worried about the second part, since so many companies successfully mess it up. Luckily, CD Project did. not. Yes, it is different in certain aspects - the fighting system is different, for instance. In my opinion, it is better. It certainly feels more fluent. The 'playing cards' are gone - but then, you won't get as many chances to seduce women, due to the story. Which, by the way, is far easier to follow and goes forward faster - which is way this game can seem much shorter than the first part, even though it actually isn't. Other things like the quality of the story, graphics or atmosphere have not changed but remain on a very, very high level.   So, yes, I recommend buying this game. For all the reasons stated above and for the additional one that by buying this game, one supports a great game studio which does everything right when it comes to supporting their community. Doubly important in a time of 'Let's screw our stupid customers over with overpriced DLCs and DRM!'

I had originally played “The Witcher 2” on the X360 and now replaying it again in anticipation of “The Witcher 3”. I got to say after coming out in 2011 it still holds up.  Here’s the skinny: • It has incredible visuals with the environment, character/enemy designs and textures being incredible eye-catchers that will have you wanting to play on the highest settings you can get. • If you love RPGs you will love this game. It is not as large as Skyrim but because of that the details are much finer and better. It has extensive level up systems, crafting, equipment and combat varieties that I believe are essential in RPG gameplay. • The combat overall is strategic, if you try to brute force your way it may take you several deaths and tries to progress. You will need to make use of all resources • The story is incredible with your different choices in game that will results in a variety of endings for this game. But to see if our choices will have true impact we will have to wait for “The Witcher 3” to come out and see if our imported “Witcher 2” files will do any impact on the story or just carry over character upgrades. • It is dense with content and will give you a considerable amount of hours of entertainment. This game with its dense gameplay, in-depth story and incredible visuals and it fun factor earn it a 10/10. A game that is truly worth buying and increases my anticipation and excitement for the Witcher 3” and the conclusion to Geralt’s masterfully made adventure from CD Project Red.

The Witcher 2 is an amazing semi-open world RPG game that immerses you into a chaotic world torn down because of war and conspiracies, and as a Witcher you can interact in this world in many ways   You can : Get involved in politics , choose your allies and foes , and even outsmart the game to look for conventional solutions ' Similar to fallout 3 '    This game has many pros :    + Nice graphics   + Combat requires skills ( if you are playing on normal or hard difficulty)   + The game forces you to switch strategies ( EX : Melee, Magic or traps )   + Wonderful narrative ' The story is attractive , mysterious and interesting )   + you can get out 60+ hours of gameplay from this game   + Character development is smooth and rewarding   + Decent Side quests   + Choices are very Important ( you actually care about the choices you make )   + Nice soundtrack   + The ending is SO WOW (There is a twist / mystery in the story that you uncover in the last hours of the game)       Unfortunately this game has some annoying issues :    - minor bugs and glitches   - Some characters are easily forgettable or hard to remember since the game is filled with many Main and secondary characters  - the plot was hard to understand ' because I wasn't paying enough attention to the story :) '   - Even though the combat was tough and strategic , yet it sometimes felt weird , rough , or unresponsive   - Some quests were very difficult and required critical thinking ,prediction, and some Luck ( This can be an advantage for hardcore master race RPG fans :D ..... )   - Sometimes I felt Lost in the game not knowing what to do or where to go         To wrap up, The Withcer 2 is one of the best RPG games out there and it's one of the games worth buying for looking wonderful and telling a decent story.      8.5 / 10 ------------- Worth a buy :)

the witcher was a global phenom that apparently the US wasnt ready for during its original debut in 2007. having read 5.5 of the original 7 novels i have a better understanding of the story to date, especially having played the first game. but none of that matters as, introduced in the first game, our hero geralt, has no memory of his past, ie the novels. either way, the witcher series is about the story of geralt of rivia, a witcher or professional monster hunter, who is dragged into a twisting and turning story of political bull.sh.it that he wants nothing to do with, but unfortunitly cant escape. Unlike the first game of the series, the graphics are far more refined, the story is much more cohesive, complex and inline with what original stories would lead to, and is exactly what CDProjekt were hoping to create with the first game. not only does choice matter, it is essential to the very core of the game. every decision has a consequence, whether you see it now or at the end of your journey. this is the type of game that bioware has wet dreams about but instead sells you a half ♥♥♥ copy of. litteraly the 2nd half of the game takes completely different paths depending on a not so simple choice in the 1st chapter. one of my personal favorite features is 'survivor mode'...dont be fooled, combat can be extremely difficult in this game, but entering the arena is a nice change of pace that will give you some, albiet, over exaggerated practice, but it is a great time killer that will keep you going in the hopes taht you can get your name of the leader board. highly addictive and extremely punishing to the say the least, especially at higher difficulty levels. sure theres flaws, very few games are without but this is a game, that even if you didnt play the first, will have you from beginning to end leaving you begging for more, and unlike most games that claim to be of the same ilk....*cough* mass effect, there actually is more to do that you can not do because of the decisions that you made the first time around. Buy this game now, especially being 5$ as it will give you some back info to Witcher 3.  p.s. if you can get your hands on teh novels, they are fantastic and really give a detailed backstory on most characters, especially geralt and his close companions. trust me you wont regret this purchase <3

This game...  My biggest critique would be the audio. Its strangely missing in some cutscenes (footsteps, sword slashes, punching noises, ambient noises), under-delivered in other instances (some crowd noise seems weak and out of place), with some dialogue drowned out by music or other ambient noise (Geralts voice actor, while awesome, is sometimes inaudible due to acompanying audio). Audio is the #1 thing in games, where if done wrong, can remove me from the experience. Animations are #2. Outside of pre-rendered cutscenes and combat, character animations are stilted and ugly. Don't go into this game expecting to see facial animations either, because they don't exist. There is just barely lip sync. While not entirely impactful on my experience with the game as a whole, I would like to critique the level design in the final chapter. Loc Muinne is a maze with very few landmarks. It was just kind of a pain getting around that level. I look forward to the sequel which promises to be open world. That would suit a game like this better. Linear level design just feels wrong. Also, the pacing in this game is off. I didn't find myself invested in the story until the end of chapter 2, which is 2/3 of the way through the game. I may be to blame for not playing the first game, or reading the books, but really... as a game designer, you have to have a plan to bring new players into the fold, and to get them interested in your story as well.   With all of that said, the game is very good. The combat is great. The story is well layered, and well delivered. In fact, its well supported as well. I found myself spacing out during several cutscenes and afterwards saying, 'OOOOOOKKKKKKK... WTF just happened again?' No problemo. Open the journal, read the journal entry for the mission I am on, and the cutscene is well summarized right there. With the awesome journal, I was able to keep up with the story, and learn a little more about the game's story. So, definetely a recommend.

Probably the most underrated CRPG out there. This game is a gemstone that stands as an example to traditional role playing game developing companies like Bethesda and Bioware. It's been developed by a Polish game company named CDProjekt with no desire to be a part of today's competitive capitalist game industry. A lot of time and effort was spent in creating this game as it's a well polished, very original rpg unlike many unripe games we see today.   It takes place in a fantasy world where three northern kingdoms, Temeria, Redenia, Kaedwen (and previously Aedirn) deal with internal turmoils as a mysterious assassin begins to collect crowned heads as in south, expantionist Nilfgaardian Empire stands ready. Also, a resistance guerilla force including non-humans called Scoi'tel emerges to fight for the oppressed and the protagonist, Geralt of Rivia finds himself in the middle of the conflict.  The atmosphere of the environments are truly amazing thanks to stunning visuals and beautiful background soundtrack. Instead of wandering through one vast geographical area like the one in Skyrim, The Witcher 2 takes place in 3 different regions and the player allowed and encouraged to explore each one in all three chapters, Temerian village of Flotsam next to a swamp-forest, Dwarven city of Vergen on top of the Blue Mountains and finally the ancient city of Loc Muinne, now in ruins.  The game's combat system is rather old-school and takes time to get used to it. Once getting familiar with it however, you will see how fun it is. You carry two swords, a steel one for humanoids and a silver one for monsters. Gerald posseses 5 magical abilites called 'Signs' allowing you to stun, ignite, trap, convert enemies along with providing protection. Alchemy system allows you to craft potions and swords oils giving you various advantages, but you need to use them 'before' the battle, not during! As Geralt finishes quests, contracts and kills monsters he levels up, providing skill points to spend in TW2's vast skill tree. Since you cannot unlock all nodes in the skill tree, you need to customize your character in Magic, Melee and Alchemy.  To sum up, if you call yourself a rpg person, you should definetly play this game. The first game of the installement is said to be very problematic but no worries, you can start of the series directly with TW2 as i did. The lore and role playing elements are well thought and captivating, encouraging you to do more than one playthroughs. It's a very cheap game for its quality. Have fun and remember, you never trust sorceresses ;)

This game is one of my favorite RPGs of all time. It has a really strong and compelling narrative and offers you plenty of chances to make choices that feel like they have some weight to them, though, perhaps not as much as the first game. The characters are mostly interesting, and the character development is definitely there. One of my favorite things about the story and characters is the moral ambiguity of it all. There is no clear distinction of good and evil between any of the sides. Simply two perspectives of what's right. The combat feels pretty fluid and I greatly enjoyed it. I liked how alchemy worked in the game, too. It's unnecessary in the first two difficulties, but in the higher ones, you'll find yourself greatly crippled if not using it. You cannot use potions in combat, so that adds some strategy to it. The game is absolutely beautiful on ultra settings, and it still looks pretty great even on lowers ones. The environment does at least. Nothing seems out of place in the world, the enemies are well designed and plenty creepy at times. They did a great job crafting the world.  That doesn't mean it's without its issues, though. The combat does seem pretty fluid, but in higher difficulties you'll find yourself rolling endlessly across the ground with your foes in hot pursuit. Blocking is often times useless, and there is very noticeable input lag on occasion. There's also a noticeable disparity between easy and normal difficulties. Easy being ridiculously so, and normal for new players likely quite challenging in the beginning. Also, though I enjoyed how alchemy works, it also leads to an obvious issue that can break the fluidity/immersion of the game. Since you can't use potions outside of battle, this leads most people to entering a fight to see which potion they should use for which resistances or buffs, loading a quicksave, and then using the potion. I love the idea and how it fits into the Witcher lore, but it needs some work. Also, either a pro or a con depending on your preferences, but it's not really an open world, and there's very few side-quests. You go from hub to hub, each having a few explorable zones mainly comprised of small passages. As far as the side-quests go, there's around 8 or so for the first 2 acts, I believe. Not really all that many. It leads to it being a fairly short game as far as RPGs go. Mentioning the choices again, I loved how they were worked into the game and they did 'feel' weighty, though they didn't really mean much. You still end up in more or less the same situations with the same people doing the same things.   And then there's the much touted 'Maturity' of the game. Yes, it may be much more so than many other RPGs, and it's definitely a dark game. The moral ambiguity definitely plays into this as well. With that said a lot of said 'maturity' seems to stem from the idea that sex jokes are funny and adult. The characters way to often bring up 'ploughing', at times it seems like every other sentence, though it's not really. It comes across as juvenile and cheap. There's mature themes throughout the game, though a lot of the perception of that seems attributed to the sexed up atmosphere. At least they removed the sex cards from the first game.   I probably missed quite a few things, this is just some stuff that came to mind. Might edit it on occasion.  I still recommend this game overall. It is quite enjoyable and the Witcher 3 is looking like a great game, so jumping into the series before that would probably be a good idea. It's on sale quite often, and even if not, it is easily worth $20 when it's not.

So I have about 10 hours into The WItcher 2, and I have to say it's really awesome. Obviously the graphics and engine are a big improvement from the first one, also the combat feels better. If that is one thing I can impart that feels the most different from the first game it's that in the first game it isn't too uncommon to be fighting 6-8 monsters sometimes at once, and not really even break a sweat, not so in 2, you really need to pay attention, and use that dodge and parry and your aards. Treat every combat as if you could die easily in it, because you probably will.  Also you can no longer drink potions during combat, you have to prepare for battles by drinking potions only when you are meditating, on the plus side, as long as you are not in combat it seems you can meditate anywhere, and do not need a fire. All in all The Witcher 2 pretty much improves on all aspects of The Witcher 1.   Just one thing: skip the tutorial, it is awful.

The epic scale of The Witcher 2: Assassins of Kings is remarkable, but it's the power of choice in an unrelentingly ugly world that makes it unforgettable. Moral ambiguity has never been so powerfully presented: the decisions you make actually matter, and the outcomes are often unforeseeable and rarely as good as you'd hope. Geralt's quest is entirely personal, driven forward by a colorful, occasionally bizarre and surprisingly believable cast of characters that really brings the game alive. It's a fantastic and well-told tale, layered over very solid mechanical underpinnings: A flexible character development system, glorious eye candy, intense combat and more than enough secondary content to camouflage its very linear nature. It's dark, it's dirty, it's sometimes flat-out depressing and it's brilliant. Big improvement to the first game

This game is a huge improvement over the first part. I honestly thought that they just fired all the people who previously worked on The Witcher and brought in a new team to make this awesome game. But nope, its still CD Projekt RED, I really don't know what happened in their offices during the course of just a few years, but they came up huge with a Witcher game that actually should've been the first in the series. It still has flaws, yes, it borrows some gameplay elements from a small list of successful titles and not as perfect in everything as it could potentially be, but they made so many improvements... It's just scary to think of it sometimes.  I'll elaborate on all the good and bad sides of this game, but I can assure you right now - this game is worth your time and money.  So, whats so good about it?    Combat is fun now. Yeah, it really is. It shares a decent amount with games like Demon's Souls & Batman (Arkham series), it's a bit simplified, but very fun. You now have daggers and traps at your disposal along with an enhanced array of bombs, you finally can dodge and block (and even parry if unlock a specific perk!) enemy attacks and topple them with improved witcher signs (still 5 signs, but they work slightly different).   Quest system is improved also, there are many interesting and cryptic side quests that requires an actual thinking before they can be solved and the game only provides 'hand holding' for quests related to the main story.   They added a huge amount of items, times where you had to choose between 3 viable swords in the first Witcher are gone. Every chapter contains at least several good swords and armors and other pieces of equipment to look for. You can even customize your armor with runes now, not only swords.   Skill trees were completely reworked. You now have 4 trees: Training, Warrior, Mage and Alchemist. Level cap now is 35 and you are forced to put 6 skill points into a Training tree which leaves you with 29 more skill points, it means that basically you can only max out one tree or mix it up between the 2 of your choice. It may sound harsh at first but that's more than enough in the end to build a very powerful character.   New adrenaline skill system introduced: each skill tree has it's own 'super ability' which you can activate by filling an adrenaline bar (it usually fills just by hitting your foes).   There's a real inventory now (yay!) where you can store weapons/armor and other things you've found. It based on the 'weight' stat, much like in Fallout 3.   Role playing is still here, you can be a bad guy killing everyone or a peaceful 'problem solver', it's up to you. You need to complete the game at least 2 times to learn and understand everything, both playthroughs will be very different.   Many memorable characters you'll encounter along your path, all with their stories and even a decent amount of drama usually.   Narrative element is still very strong and all dialogues are voiced again which is really awesome.   Game looks gorgeous and optimized much better than it's predecessor.   Now to the things I didn't quite like:   The game is pretty short. I always complete all quests, but if you just rush through the story then you probably can complete this game in under 20 hours (depending on the difficulty setting).   Difficulty is a problem yet again. There are 5 difficulty settings this time, but CD Projekt RED has some tough times balancing mid-late game witcher against his foes. When you hit mid game, like level 10-15 - the game becomes a faceroll mostly, witcher has so much power and tools to deal with anything, it's just ridiculous. The only tough mode is Insane, which is basically a hardcore mode, where you can't die even once. But considering game length and how powerful witcher can be it's not that big of a deal to beat it after completing a game once or twice.   You can now drink potions only while meditating. An unnecessary rule in my opinion considering that potion effects lasts less longer than in the first game.   Main antagonist despite having a good presentation never develops into a memorable character and boss fights vs him are extremely underwhelming. It's pretty disappointing for for such a good game.   Save system is quite bad. Each time you press 'save' game just autosaves and every time it creates a new file, not to mention all those scripted autosaves made by game after certain events. All that leads to a giant pile of save files which leads to an occasional crash while trying to load the game, to fix this you have to manually delete save files from your PC.   UI could be better. When you amass a good load of items it becomes inconvenient to scroll-search for them in such a small window.   Despite the downsides, it's still an amazing package, in my opinion it's a 'must play' for anyone who enjoys story driven or action RPGs. Well... And for the Witcher fans of course!  8/10.

This game has been around for a long time now and I'm sure almost everyone has played it for at least a couple of hours. But maybe you jumped straight to Witcher 3 and want to come back to this one.  I'll start with the PROS: - It has a beautiful story; - The characters are well-drawn and believable, almost all of them; - The choices you make matter; - Visually, it is a beautiful game, but not perfect; - The atmosphere is pleasant; - Ii is difficult, but in a good way.  Here are some of the flaws: It could have been longer. The combat mechanics could have much been more complex, The saved games system is very poor. You can't overwrite or arrange saved games. The looting system is a joke for a RPG. You can steal almost everything in the game without consequences. The side quests could offer more details, You have to use potions before a fight and not during it. Vigor doesn't replenish while Quen is active, thus limiting your playstyle. Game crashed quite often.  To sum up, Witcher 2 is a good game, but not perfect. You might like it or you'll be disappointed. For me, the story and characters helped me overlook some of flaws. It does take a while to be captivated by the game, so I advise you to be patient.

The story is very good, I like the mature tone it keeps in this fantasy world. Its a great game except for some minor issues: I've started like 6 plathroughs but only finished once, mostly because I got tired of running around looking for something (completionist) and not finding it (for a very long time). Great graphics although it could use a bit of optimizing. The DoF is so aggressive its annoying as hell therefore I always keep it off. The sword play (the only way to play the game) is fun at times but tedious when playing in Dark difficulty; each fight becomes a minigame, hit once or twice lowering the enemy's health by one pixel and roll back to avoid getting hit (otherwise loose 1/3 of your health and sometimes getting insta-killed). Could use more customization options in-game, such as keeping only the 3 last autosaves. I have to keep manually deleting them otherwise the main menu will take forever to load because of so many saves. Also the game autosaves at very unconvenient times, so I stick to quicksaves most of the times.

Performance:  Really impressed with how well-made the new engine is. Loads faster(which is kind of surprising because the first game's load times weren't even long), stutters less, and, of course, looks prettier. And I mean much prettier. You don't expect games that look this much better than their prequels to actually perform better than them.  The only things about it that I don't like are the differed rendering(alternate form of rendering that only supports [and works] [with] a form of anti-aliasing that has been specifically coded into the game, cancelling out any kind of AA forced on from your graphics control panel. Use SweetFX for AA.), sharpness filter(you'll wanna turn it off in your user config, but make sure to force Anisotrophic Filtering on), and the bloom. The bloom.. I usually am ok with bloom in my games, but I had to turn this game's off. There is just too much of it. For my eyes, anyway.  Graphics settings: Many graphics settings available for tweaking. There's a lot you can make changes to that will help the game run better on your rig, if it needs it  Controls: Controls are greatly improved. Dodging actually works consistently, unlike in the last game. Same with parrying. Same with attacking. I remember instances in the first Witcher where the system sometimes wouldn't let me attack opponents if they were close to me or surrounded me or just didn't let me attack them(while not stunned, etc). When attacking, you use either the left or right mouse button. Either are for heavy or light attacks. Is not like the first Witcher where you select an attack style and click on a foe. The buttons are the styles, so they have to be used/pressed after each attack. Can be combined.  They took out the feature that let's you press/hold a button/key to highlight/display whatever in view can be interacted with, as well as the the feature that's you select what you want to interact with the cursor, while you hold/press a button. It's not that big of a deal not having it, but you now have to just run up to something you see, and click on it to do whatever with it.  Gameplay: Am a few hours into the game, but can say it's very much like the first. Only, better.  Combat is same, but more engaging. Also kinda harder(but I was playing on Dark/Insane difficulty.). You can meditate anywhere(no fireplaces/characters needed) that wouldn't be considered dangerous(out of battle, not in the presence of enemies). Inside or outside.  So far, the choice system is still here. I've been in situations in the game where I could, as an example, stop a crime or let it follow through. There are also sub-choices, which can sometimes be made after main choices have been made. Good/bad/etc ones are available.  EDIT:  Overall: Have since spent more hours playing the game and am enjoying it. The story is very much still that of The Witcher's, and the gameplay is very fun. Good combat, and there more options for interacting with characters you encounter than there were in last Witcher game.  The game feels like it was made on PC, which is awesome. Same as the last game. Same level of detail in the enviornments, great graphics, and doesn't feel like some technically-constrained console port.  'coughs' Skyrim 'coughs' Fallout

In general, The Witcher 2 is extremely well executed and I sincerely enjoyed nearly everything about the game (minus a few miniscule things, which I will detail)  The GOOD things:  - Plotline is superb. The Witcher 2 is based on a novel and the story is top notch quality writing. Real LOTR type stuff. - The choices you make throughout the adventure determine how the game ends. The Witcher 2 actually has 8 different endings depending on the choices you make, and these choices are actually impactful (for example, MAIN characters can live or die depending on what you do). You can easily play though this game multiple times and get a different story line/ending each time. - Characterization is probably the best I have seen in any game of this scale. It is hard not to care about what happens to the cast in this game. You either love or hate the characters because they have fully realized personalities and motives. If you consider how many main characters there are, along with all the of the different plotlines which are occurring, then this could not have been an easy feat to accomplish. - The combat system is well executed. It is not sluggish or boring and it allows you to fight in many different combat styles if you choose to do so. - The visuals in this game are simply stunning. If you compare The Witcher 2 to Skyrim, which came out within six months of eachother, The Witcher 2 blows Skyrim out of the water in terms of graphics and visuals.  The BAD things: - There is no fast travel feature. There is a lot of walking around. It's not so bad that it breaks the game, but it is quite noticeable and it begs the question of why such a simple time saving feature was not placed into the game. - Again, like in the original Witcher, you don't ever use the crafting/gold/enhancement items you collect unless you spend a lot of time and go out your way to do so. I felt like this was a big area the designers could improve on from the orignal, but it never happened.  - Some of the difficulty in the game is not quite balanced. For example the first chapter is probably the hardest one because you have zero gear or defenses and the mobs will just ♥♥♥♥ on you. As you progress and get better gear and talent points, the mobs literally become meaningless because you scale above them so drastically. Better balance was needed for sure.  Overall though, again, The Witcher 2 is excellent. The most important aspects of the game (the story and the actual combat) are executed extremely well. After playing The Witcher 2 I find it hard to believe that Skyrim received so much praise even though they were released within six months of eachother. The main thing Skyrim has over Witcher 2 is better character combat/thieving customization, but the story and characters in Skyrim are just horrendous. I suppose it depends on what you are looking for in a game.The Witcher 2 takes about 20 hours to finish.  Oh, and Philippa Eilhart is such a babe.  9.5/10  Please upvote this review if you found it useful :)

I picked this game up a year ago as my first PC game and I'm almost done with it. I'm not even quite at the end and can already say it's one of my favorite games ever. Medievel settings usually don't really appeal to me but it doesn't even matter to me because this game is so well done and despite some of the olde fashioned dialogue, the characters seem like very real people. I think why I really like this game other than it simply being extremely solid all around, what really sets it apart is the way its quests are put together. Most RPG's have rather shallow side quests that frequently consist of 'I lost this item in a dangerous place, will you get it back for me?' But in The Witcher 2 everything is much deeper and each quest has a unique story line, usually with multiple paths and interesting characters. It's nice that the moral decisions aren't so black and white like alot of games and leave you really pondering what you should do. So going into this game with 6 years later with no nostalgia, I can honestly say it holds up fantastically! And at the price it frequently goes for, I think it's hands down the best value there is in gaming, I can't think of a better way to spend $3. It is not open world which may be a sign of its era, but each segmented township area are so detailed and are in fact very open with so much to do, it almost feels like an open world game even though the map has specific paths laid out for you with many semi-invisible walls. You'll want to make sure you do everything you can before carrying onto the next area. Definitely can't wait to play Witcher 3, I can only imagine what I'm in for.  For the record I played through most the game with a Dualshock 4, despite what some say I find the game works very well with a controller.

(Played because people can't stop praising the third game and I have a long holiday to clean the backlog) Terrible first half, competent second half, ordinary fantasy RPG with lifesaving flavor.  Strange and floaty combat system prevents stops dead any funhaving in the game - until you finally get proper swords, proper skills in the tree and become a glass cannon depending on protection sign spamming. Maybe it was a revelation when it came out (I recall savage fights about this vs. Dragon Age and Skyrim, also not very good games), it does not hold a candle to the combat in Souls games or Dragons Dogma.  [PRESS LMB TO CLIMB A LEDGE][PRESS LMB TO CLIMB A LEDGE][PRESS LMB TO CLIMB A LEDGE]  Story is not impressive, but I am biased against any kind of fantasy with dragons, kings and elves. Sustain a siege, collect bear asses, help peasants, make friends, woof. Yet, the world is not without bright spots: the visual design of clothes is stunning, there are several amazing setpieces and quests (Battle in the Mist, the ghost Asylum), being played and screwed by Big Game politics is refreshing (compared to world-saving plots). Wish it was a game about Letho instead (hell, most characters in the game are more interesting that Geralt). I would rather converse by text message on that phone about the 'moon back tonight' than play another combat in Witcher 2.  Others have listed the specific flaws in game play, so I don't need to. I suspect there exists a big divide in opinion between people with a controller and those without.  I played the first Witcher. Its combat mechanics were too simple to present a challenge, but the simplicity of the controls was praiseworthy. That heightened my dismay over all the keys needed during action in Witcher 2. This was one of the biggest disappointments i have ever had. You dont conserve any levels or skills. Sure the game itself is the witcher but those points i mention just turn down the fun for me. I love the witcher 1, sure it had it's flaws as well. I got this game a while ago on a steam sale, and due to a combination of skeptisim, graphics card problems, and a missing PC xbox controller, I never got around to play it until recently.   After finally playing it, I'm blown away, this is a fantastic game. Don't get me wrong, it isn't perfect, there are a lot of little issues with it. There are a good number of bugs. The third act felt short. The game can be a little immature/mysoginistic (I enjoy a bit of ♥♥♥♥ and and sex in games, what bothered me was how a lot of the women were portrayed). And worst is that there were a lot of game elements (especially mutations) that seemed really good but were painfully under-utilized. Ultimately, even with all these issues, the game is fantastic, the combat, strategy, upgrading and crafting all felt great (I was skeptical about the potion mechanic but actually quite enjoyed the strategy and planning it added).  I would give this game a solid 8.5 / 10. It was very fun to play, and the story and roleplaying were enjoyable. I now plan to replay the game, bring up the difficulty, and maybe try some different story and upgrade paths. I am now quite excited for the Witcher 3, and hope that it will improve upon the game and be an even greater experience.

The Witcher 2 is at heart a faily straightforward western RPG. It gives you a decent area to roam around, some fairly standard enemies to hack'n'slash, skills to upgrade, cutomization and upgrading, and your choices effect the story.   It can be pretty hard in the beginning stages, only because this is isn't Skyrim where you can run in and tank against 30 draugr, in this 3 guys could easily kill you, you need strategy. Once you learn how to fight without getting killed instantly(Quen sign baby!) it becomes much easier, and if you level well the end game is very easy.  My only gripes are that sometimes it's hard to find/finish quests, the 3 areas you have to explore aren't very large, there is a good amount of backtracking, and the rather large difficulty swing. Still an excellent game.
